Issues.Title: feat(bazel): allow passing and rewriting an old bazel host
Issues.Body:
Updates the decision made in #31341; this is for the Angular indexer
inside Google. The indexer currently passes (and ngc-wrapped#compile
accepts) a bazel host to use, but because many methods are overwritten
specially for Angular compilation a better approach is to pass an old
bazel compiler host and siphon methods needed off of it before creating
a new host. This enables the later approach.

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
  - n/a
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
The indexer currently passes (and ngc-wrapped#compile accepts) a bazel host to use.

## What is the new behavior?
`ngc-wrapped#compile` accepts an old bazel compiler host and siphons methods off of it before creating a new host.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No

This breaks the Angular indexer inside Google. Is it highly unlikely that anyone is using this API. Migration plan is to change the `bazelHost` property passed to `compile` to `oldBazelHost`.

## Other information
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(bazel): allow passing and rewriting an old bazel host" (#31381)

Issues.Title: fix(common): expand type for "ngForOf" input to work with strict null checks
Issues.Body:
Currently the `ngForOf` input accepts `null` or `undefined` as valid values. Though
when using strict template input type checkign (which will be supported by `ngtsc`),
passing `null` or `undefined` with strict null checks enabled causes a type check
failure because the type for the `ngForOf` input becomes too strict if strict null checks
are enabled. The type of the input needs to be expanded to also accept `null` or
`undefined` to behave consistent (ignoring the `strictNullChecks` flag).

This is necessary because whenever strict input type checking is enabled
by default, most of the Angular projects that use `*ngFor` with the async pipe
will either need to disable template type checking or strict null checks because
the `async` pipe returns `null` if the observable hasn't been emitted yet.

See for example how this affects the `angular/components` repository and how
much pain the workaround involves: https://github.com/angular/components/pull/16373.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(common): expand type for "ngForOf" input to work with strict null checks" (#31371)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): handle namespaced imports correctly
Issues.Body:
The ngcc tool adds namespaced imports to files when compiling. The ngtsc
tooling was not processing types correctly when they were imported via
such namespaces. For example:

```
export declare class SomeModule {
    static withOptions(...): ModuleWithProviders<Éµngcc1.BaseModule>;
```

In this case the `BaseModule` was being incorrectly attributed to coming
from the current module rather than the imported module, represented by
`Éµngcc1`.

Fixes #31342

Issues.Title: App doesn't work in Firefox/Waterfox after updating it to Version 8
Issues.Body:
We have updated an Angular app from version 7.2 to version 8. The update process has worked so far and the app can be used locally and in prod mode (on the server) on Chrome, Firefox Developer Edition, Safari, Opera as usual.

***But in the normal Firefox browser and Waterfox, the app does not work:***

- The app tries to render while the browser shows the status ***"Performing a tls handshake to localhost"***, until at some point a ***"The connection has timed out"*** comes.
- In prod mode, after I have deployed the app, at least the login mask shows up but the performance of the app is so bad that hardly nothing works.

***We have created a browserlist file with the following content:***

    # This file is used by the build system to adjust CSS and JS output to support the specified browsers below.
    # For additional information regarding the format and rule options, please see:
    # https://github.com/browserslist/browserslist#queries
    
    # You can see what browsers were selected by your queries by running:
    # npx browserslist
    
    > 0.5%
    last 2 versions
    Firefox ESR
    not dead
    not IE 9-11 # For IE 9-11 support, remove 'not'.

***Our tsconfig looks like this:***

    {
    Â Â "compileOnSave": false,
    Â Â "compilerOptions": {
    Â Â Â Â "downlevelIteration": true,
    Â Â Â Â "importHelpers": true,
    Â Â Â Â "outDir": "./dist/out-tsc",
    Â Â Â Â "baseUrl": "src",
    Â Â Â Â "sourceMap": true,
    Â Â Â Â "declaration": false,
    Â Â Â Â "moduleResolution": "node",
    Â Â Â Â "emitDecoratorMetadata": true,
    Â Â Â Â "experimentalDecorators": true,
    Â Â Â Â "target": "es2015",
    Â Â Â Â "typeRoots": [
    Â Â Â Â Â Â "Node_modules / @ types"
    Â Â Â Â ]
    Â Â Â Â "lib": [
    Â Â Â Â Â Â "ES2016"
    Â Â Â Â Â Â "Dom"
    Â Â Â Â ]
    Â Â Â Â "module": "esnext"
    Â Â }
    }

***And the area with the ssl configuration inside the angular.json so:***

      "serve": {
        "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:dev-server",
        "options": {
          "browserTarget": "farm-management-ui:build",
          "port": 8080,
          "ssl": true,
          "proxyConfig": "src/proxy.conf.js"
        },

***We have already successfully executed the following commands:***

**ng update @ angular / cli --from 7 --to 8 --migrate - only**

**ng update @ angular / core - from 7 - to 8 --migrate-only**

And I have the feeling that if the app is running in Firefox an endless loop is created, because I can't also open other webpages like Stackoverflow and so on..

Why does Firefox suddenly have this behavior and how can we fix this?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "App doesn't work in Firefox/Waterfox after updating it to Version 8" (#31364)

Issues.Title: Compiling sass with bazel
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ bug report ### Is this a regression? There is feature missing for bazel pipeline. ### Description Build angular pipeline allows for adding global style preprocessor options, in particular includePaths option for Sass and Stylus. https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/wiki/stories-global-styles When using bazel, [multi_sass_binary](https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_sass#multi_sass_binary) is used to, but it doesn't allow for passing includePaths. There is a relevant request in rules_sass repository. https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_sass/issues/90 Additionaly include_paths option takes paths, not labels, therefore its problematic to pass directories from other packages. It's common to include some directory containing partial scss files from node_modules, currently it's impossible to reference them directly. ## ğŸŒ Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Issues.Title: Forced to use bypassSecurityTrustResourceUrl to avoid getting (WARNING: sanitizing unsafe URL)
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ bug report ### Description So, I'm trying to download a base64 file from the client app, say a pdf file or a word document. In order to achieve this I would have to set the href attribute of an "a" tag with the base64 value of the file. This causes a warning [WARNING: sanitizing unsafe URL]. The logical solution for this would be to sanitize the file in order to ensure no XSS is possible and to stop getting the error. So, I tried using the sanitize function as the following: `const sanitizedURL = this.domSanitizer.sanitize(` `SecurityContext.URL /* context to sanitize */,` `unsafeURL);` However, this wouldn't work. I still get the same error. I searched online and everyone kept saying to use the bypassSecurityTrustUrl function, which I did. I sanitized the file using sanitize function then went along and passed it to the bypassSecurityTrustUrl to inform it that it's safe URL. However, it still wouldn't work. The only way for me to get rid of the error is to use bypassSecurityTrustUrl on the un-sanitized URL of the file, which doesn't really make sense. This will still make my app vulnerable to XSS attacks. I'm trying to follow the safe approach for this, but it feels like I'm being forced to use bypassSecurityTrustUrl on it's own for it to work, which is not the behavior I want as that URL is always from the user. ## ğŸ”¥ Exception or Error 

WARNING: sanitizing unsafe URL
## ğŸŒ Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 7.3.7
Node: 8.9.1
OS: darwin x64

Issues.Title: Injection by the equivalent (but not same instance) of the InjectionToken does not work
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ bug report ### Affected Package `@angular/core` ### Is this a regression? Not sure ### Description When provider defines binding for `InjectionToken` (rather than for Type), the injection can be made only with the same instance of `InjectionToken`. It's expected to work with the equivalent InjectionToken as well. ```typescript const token1 = new InjectionToken('MyInjectionToken'); const token2 = new InjectionToken('MyInjectionToken'); const injector = Injector.create({providers: [ { provide: token1, useValue: 'My value' } ]}) // Expected: injection should succeed, // Actual: exception is thrown const injectedValue = injector.get(token2); ``` ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction [reproduction at stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-issue-repro2-snbyse) ## ğŸ”¥ Exception or Error 

preview-4adb70f742b91f09679fb.js:1 ERROR Error: StaticInjectorError[InjectionToken MyInjectionToken]: 
  NullInjectorError: No provider for InjectionToken MyInjectionToken!
    at NullInjector.get (injector.ts:39)
    at resolveToken (injector.ts:334)
    at tryResolveToken (injector.ts:276)
    at StaticInjector.get (injector.ts:156)
    at AppComponent.ngOnInit (VM2377 app.component.ts:21)
    at checkAndUpdateDirectiveInline (provider.ts:205)
    at checkAndUpdateNodeInline (view.ts:429)
    at checkAndUpdateNode (view.ts:389)
    at debugCheckAndUpdateNode (services.ts:429)
    at debugCheckDirectivesFn (services.ts:390)
## ğŸŒ Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
6.1.1
Reproduced also with Angular 8 **Anything else relevant?**

Issues.Title: Report which polyfills might be missing
Issues.Body:
# ğŸš€ Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [x ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
It would be great if angular-cli can automatically warn the developer on build if a polyfill is missing which would cause trouble for some browsers.

Of course, a list of targetted browsers should be configured to look for functions that need polyfills for.

Why?

I just added `CustomEvent` to a component, and I hadn't known until I received a Sentry error from a user visiting the website using IE11 that `CustomEvent` does not exist natively.

### Describe the solution you'd like
During the build, check for functions that require polyfills according to the configure targetted browsers. Show a warning while building.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Set up multi-browser testing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Report which polyfills might be missing" (#14954)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): deprecate scripts and styles `laâ€¦
Issues.Body:
â€¦zy` option in favor of`inject`

The lazy option inside the script and style option is confusing as this option doesn't lazy load a bundle but rather it doesn't inject/reference the script in the HTML. While this option is an enabler for lazy loading, the users will still need to handle on how how this bundle will be lazy loaded. There are also potential use cases beyond lazy loading for the option.

Closes #14814

Issues.Title: Custom compiler(transpiler) options for ngtools/webpack
Issues.Body:
# ğŸš€ Feature request
Additional compiler(transpiler) options for ngtools/webpack

### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
Setting different compiler is needed sometimes, especially if we would like to use custom TypeScript transformers. In this particular case the best option is "ttypescript" but there could be other as well. It should only support compilers that have same interface as "typescript".

### Describe the solution you'd like
It would be great if we could set which compiler will be used, as in https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-loader ```compiler``` option. The perfect location for choosing the compiler in MY opinion would be tsconfig 

### Describe alternatives you've considered
I've tried to use custom loaders and override tsx files compilation, but the issue in this case is that everything that's done in ngtools/webpack will be left out, like including html templates, and probably many other things related to AoT.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Custom compiler(transpiler) options for ngtools/webpack" (#14947)

Issues.Body:
Currently there are unsolved problems with prettier. The big ones being

- PRs don't pass prettier check in CI if the PR is not exactly one commit on top of master(This can be fixed)
- Code reviews are messed up because unrelated lines are formatted and pollute the PR and impossible for reviewer to focus on the actual change

Joey is going to be looking at common formatting solution across various Angular projects.

Issues.Title: fix(@ngtools/webpack): NGCC should process secondary entry-points
Issues.Body:
Previously secondary entry-points, e.g
`@angular/common/http`,  were being resolved to
the primary entry-point, e.g `@angular/common`.
This meant that these entry-points were not being
processed as part of a compilation leading to error messages.

This change inverts the `tryResolvePackage` logic
to attempt to use `require.resolve()` first and only
looking in the parent directory of the typings file
as a fallback if the main resolve fails.

Fixes https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/30972#issuecomment-506428267
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@ngtools/webpack): NGCC should process secondary entry-points" (#14934)

Issues.Title: NodeModuleEngineHost tightly coupled to process working directory
Issues.Body:
# ğŸš€ Feature request

### Description
This is a request for a minor change.

The schematics_cli and angular_cli assume that they will be called from inside a project directory that contains the installed schematics. 

I have no issue with this, however, if I wanted to build an alternative CLI (or Electron application (which is what I intend to do)) that won't be executed from the directory that contains the schematics but instead references an alternative directory, then I need to rebuilt this entire class (or at least subclass and override the _resolveCollectionPath method).  This has highlighted that this class is tightly coupled to process.cwd and that this should instead be passed as an argument.

**More details**
 
Class NodeModulesEngineHost. Whilst methods _resolvePackageJson, _resolvePath accept a path to be provided, _resolveCollectionPath uses process.cwd() when calling them. This means that this class will always use the processes current working directory to identify schematics.

Instead, in my opinion, the class that creates the NodeModulesEngineHost should provide the baseDir. i.e. add (private path: string) to the constructor and then update the cli implementations to pass the path.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "NodeModuleEngineHost tightly coupled to process working directory" (#14935)

Issues.Title: fix(bottom-sheet): not moving focus to container if autoFocus is disabled and focus was moved while animating
Issues.Body:
These changes incorporate #16297 and #16221 into the bottom sheet since it follows a similar focus capturing behavior to `MatDialogContainer`. They ensure that focus is on the bottom sheet container when the animation is over, because it could've moved while we were animating. It also has an extra check to ensure that we don't move focus unnecessarily if the consumer decided to move focus themselves somewhere within the bottom sheet.

**Note:** does not include a unit test, because we need to be able to flush a `Promise.resolve` and an animation in a specific sequence, however the testing utilities flush them all at the same time.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(bottom-sheet): not moving focus to container if autoFocus is disabled and focus was moved while animating" (#16418)

Issues.Title: schematic(theme): inject a palette definition for customization
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description
Currently, users need to dig into `node_modules/@angular/material/_theming.scss` and find a palette like `$mat-blue` and then manually copy that into their `styles.scss` and modify it in order to create a custom palette.

This used to be easier in AngularJS Material where you could just extend an existing theme and make minor modifications.

#### Use Case
1. The most common case that I have seen is that developers want to tweak the contrast colors of a specific theme. 
1. However, it is also common to need to change just 1 or 2 colors, in an existing palette, slightly to match company branding.
1. In some cases, there is a need to create a completely custom palette, or set of palettes, for use in an application with highly custom theming.

#### Proposal

`ng g @angular/material:palette --base=mat-blue --path=src/styles.scss my-blue`

This would inject the following into `src/styles.scss` immediately after `@include mat-core();`:
```scss
$my-blue: (
  50: #e3f2fd,
  100: #bbdefb,
  200: #90caf9,
  300: #64b5f6,
  400: #42a5f5,
  500: #2196f3,
  600: #1e88e5,
  700: #1976d2,
  800: #1565c0,
  900: #0d47a1,
  A100: #82b1ff,
  A200: #448aff,
  A400: #2979ff,
  A700: #2962ff,
  contrast: (
    50: $dark-primary-text,
    100: $dark-primary-text,
    200: $dark-primary-text,
    300: $dark-primary-text,
    400: $dark-primary-text,
    500: $light-primary-text,
    600: $light-primary-text,
    700: $light-primary-text,
    800: $light-primary-text,
    900: $light-primary-text,
    A100: $dark-primary-text,
    A200: $light-primary-text,
    A400: $light-primary-text,
    A700: $light-primary-text,
  )
);
```

It would still be up to the developer to actually use the palette in defining a theme (i.e. `$app-primary: mat-palette($my-blue);`).

Relates to https://github.com/angular/components/issues/16416.
Related [Custom theming Docs](https://material.angular.io/guide/theming#defining-a-custom-theme).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "schematic(theme): inject a palette definition for customization" (#16417)

Issues.Title: schematic(theme): migrate project from prebuilt to custom theme
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description
This actually came in through the Angular CLI feedback survey, but there is interest in having a `ng generate` schematic for migrating an app using a prebuilt theme to the custom theme configuration that `ng add` already supports.

#### Use Case
Many times at `ng add` time, users don't know why they would need a custom theme or don't know that they will need one. There are a number of gotchas and ways to get implementing a custom theme wrong. Having a schematic for this would help streamline that experience and fits well without our goals for Angular Material schematics.

It's likely that a good deal of our existing `ng add` logic for adding a custom theme could be re-used. It looks like the `ng add` logic already handles things like adding a custom theme to a project that only uses CSS (it adds a `custom-theme.scss` file and then adds that to the `styles` array in the `angular.json`).

There may be a need to allow the caller to point to the files where they import their prebuilt theme, as they may have moved it out of `src/styles.scss`. But maybe it's possible to walk the imports to find it?

#### Proposal

`ng g @angular/material:customTheme`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "schematic(theme): migrate project from prebuilt to custom theme" (#16416)

Issues.Title: Form field Floating labels gaps not customizable and not taking into account the label actual size
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description
So here is the thing. Since no dense mode and since we have a custom looking material inputs, I had to make my own customization on the scss theme of the form field. The problem appeared when I changed the font size and the font itself of the floating label. Suddenly I saw that the borders are overlapping the text.
```
const floatingLabelScale = 0.75;
const outlineGapPadding = 5;
```
these values are based on some assumption that the label size will never be customized.
Now, in order to override this behavior I had to create my own directive that changes the values 
and recalculate the gaps. 
So I would like to request a change of this logic to calculate gaps dynamically, or to expose these 2 numbers as inputs or something that can be changed from outside. I'm ok with an injection token as well.

#### Use Case

In order to allow more customization features and be able to change the font-size of the floating label.

Issues.Title: fix(portal): running change detection before nodes have been moved to outlet
Issues.Body:
Currently we run change detection as soon as we create a portal's embedded view and afterwards we transfer its DOM nodes into the portal outlet. This is problematic, because running change detection also executes any lifecycle hooks which means that directives inside the portal, which are looking at the DOM, will be invoked while the element is still at its old location.

**Note:** marking this as a P2, because it's a fairly small change and it's fixing something that's caused other timing-related issues for us in the past.

Fixes #16346.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(portal): running change detection before nodes have been moved to outlet" (#16407)

Issues.Title: .cdk-overlay-pane does not fit .cdk-overlay-container
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-overlay-scroll
2. Scroll body
3. Press 'overlay' button
 
 
#### Expected Behavior 

`.cdk-overlay-pane` fits `.cdk-overlay-container` if `BlockScrollStrategy` is used.


#### Actual Behavior

`.cdk-overlay-pane` does not fit `.cdk-overlay-container` if `BlockScrollStrategy` is used.
A part of `.cdk-overlay-pane` is out `.cdk-overlay-container`.
There is no way to scroll to the bottom of the last `.overlay-items__item`.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8931568/60344410-2c25f880-99bf-11e9-8f0b-b53deda63a53.png)


#### Environment

- Angular: 7, 8
- CDK/Material: 7, 8
- Browser(s): Google Chrome, Firefox, Opera
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows, macOS, Android

#### Suggest a Fix
I have found two ways to fix it.
1. Make `OverlayConfig#minHeight` required
2. Set default value of `OverlayConfig#minHeight`

Issues.Title: Hide panel of autocomplete on focus
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

What I would like to see is an option to disable the panel on focus.

#### Use Case

When a user focus on an autocomplete input I want the panel to be not opened.
After input it will open the panel.

#### What I tried

I have an FormArray within that FormArray I have multiple autocompletes.
For the phone the autocompletes are wrapped in an expansion panel.
When either the page open with default expansion panel or when a epansion panel get clicked it will selected the first input, in this case an autocomplete.
The autocomplete open with the panel open.
I can close it with `this.autoCompletes['_results'][0].closePanel();` which is a queryList of MatAutocompleteTrigger.
This will close the panel when I open the page.
But it doesn't if I open an expansion panel.
So I tried to add this on the focus event.
It seems that the panel will open after the focus event.
So the panel get closed before the panel get opened.

Also tried a timeout but this will first visible show the panel and then close it.

#### Solution

Either make the panel open earlier.
Make an input to disable the panel on focus.

#### Stackblitz
https://angular-sng8gx.stackblitz.io
Query list is not working for some reason..

#### Edit
I changed it to this, it seems to work better but after the second input it get registered sadly.
It seems matAutocompleteDisabled is set to late.
```
(focus)="closedPanel=true;"
(input)="getData($event.target).then(closedPanel=false);"
[matAutocompleteDisabled]="closedPanel"
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Hide panel of autocomplete on focus" (#16401)

Issues.Title: change mat-sidenav content dynamically from any component
Issues.Body:
#### What are you trying to do?

I am trying to load different components in mat-sidenav from different routed components based on some action like button click?

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

I have created a singleton service 'SidenavService' to get reference to mat-sidenav using @ViewChild,  this way I can control (like open, close, toggle etc.) sidenav from anywhere in the app.

I have also created a ng-container in mat-sidenav and stored its ViewConteinerRef in SidenavService, now in any component in component hierarchy, I can inject the SidenavService and I can use ViewConteinerRef  to created embedded view.

#### What are you seeing that does not match your expectations? 

Is there a better way to achieve this? loading different components in mat-sidenav from anywhere in the app.

#### Reproduction

stackblitz link
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-material-sidenav-dynamic-content

Steps to reproduce:
1. demoed in stackblitz
  
#### Environment

Issues.Title: Chip autocomplete doesn't support showing error colour and message
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-n6tpca?file=app/chips-autocomplete-example.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. select a fruit, and then remove it. The boolean display TRUE (invalid) all the time because we set the input formControl to null. The input is invalid, but the invalid class is not projected to the mat-form-field. 


 
 
#### Expected Behavior

When removing all chips, I expect to see a red border and red label, and the mat-error tag should display.


#### Actual Behavior

No error behaviour is displayed.
It could be that this is happening since the input tag is nested in the `mat-chip-list`, and can't find the parent element to apply the styles to.

Manually adding `ng-invalid && mat-form-field-invalid` via the ngClass directive does work.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8,0.2
- CDK/Material:8.01
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): MacOS Mojave
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Chip autocomplete doesn't support showing error colour and message" (#16393)
